article:
'Deism' ( .  or ) is the belief that reason and observation
of the natural world are sufficient to determine the existence of God,
accompanied with the rejection of revelation and authority as a source of
religious knowledge. {{cite encyclopedia
 | title = Deism encyclopedia = Encyclopedia Britannica year = 2012
 | url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/156154/Deism quote=In general,
 | Deism refers to what can be called natural religion, the acceptance of a
 | certain body of religious knowledge that is inborn in every person or that
 | can be acquired by the use of reason and the rejection of religious
 | knowledge when it is acquired through either revelation or the teaching of
 | any church. }}








 Deism gained prominence in the 17th and 18th centuries during the Age of
Enlightenmentâespecially in Britain, France, Germany, and Americaâamong
intellectuals raised as Christians who believed in one god, but found fault with
organized religion and could not believe in supernatural events such as
miracles, the inerrancy of scriptures, or the Trinity.

Deism is derived from [[deus]], the Latin word for god. The earliest known usage
in print of the English term deist is 1621, {{Cite web
| last=Burton first=Robert authorlink=Robert Burton (scholar) work=The Anatomy
| of Melancholy title=first-found usage of "deist" year=1621 at=p. 687 Part III,
| section IV. II. i quote=CoÆin Germans to theÆe men, are many of our great
| PhiloÆophers and DeiÆts url=http://books.google.com/?id=cPgveWnCdRcC&printsec-
| =frontcover&dq=anatomy+of+melancholy
}} and deism is first found in a 1675 dictionary.
{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/?id=CFBGAAAAYAAJ&pg=PT255&dq=deism#v=o-
nepage&q=deism&f=false |title=An universal etymological English dictionary
|first=Nathan |last=Bailey |year=1675 | accessdate=2011-04-09}}  {{cite web
| url=http://www.google.com/search?q=deism&hl=en&lr=lang_en&sa=X&ei=laN0TYJXhri-
| xA-
| jP2cwL&ved=0CBoQpwUoBA&source=lnt&tbs=bks:1,lr:lang_1en,cdr:1,cd_min:1/1/1621-
| ,cd_max:12/31/1681&tbm=#q=deism&hl=en&lr=lang_en&sa=X&ei=mqN0Tc6jJozUtQOax43I-
| Cw&ved=0CBoQpwUoBA&source=lnt&tbs=bks:1%2Clr%3Alang_1en%2Ccdr%3A1%2Ccd_min%3A-
| 1%2F1%2F1621%2Ccd_max%3A12%2F31%2F1681&tbm=&bav=on.2,or.&fp=d73c05de5384b6af
| title=Googlebooks.com search for "Deism" in years 1621-1681}}
 Deistic ideas influenced several leaders of the American and French
Revolutions.  Two main forms of deism currently
exist: classical deism and modern deism.
